verses.text: My son, pay attention to my wisdom; lend your ear to my understanding,
verses.comment: The call to 'my son' echoes the parental wisdom motif in Proverbs. The emphasis on listening recalls the Shema (Deut. 6:4), central to community life and obedience to God's law.

verses.text: so that you may keep discretion, and your lips may safeguard knowledge.
verses.comment: Knowledge and discretion are presented as treasures to be guarded, connecting to wisdom literature's portrayal of wisdom as life-giving (Prov. 3:18).

verses.text: For the lips of a strange woman drip honey, and her speech is smoother than oil;
verses.comment: The 'strange woman' symbolizes temptation and sin. Her alluring words represent the subtlety of moral danger—a theme which is spiritual as well as literal.

verses.text: but in the end she is as bitter as wormwood, sharp as a two-edged sword.
verses.comment: Wormwood in Scripture often refers to bitterness and God's judgment (Jer. 9:15; Rev. 8:11). The sword imagery alludes to deadly consequences—spiritual death and separation.

verses.text: Her feet go down to death; her steps lead straight to Sheol.
verses.comment: Sheol indicates the grave or the realm of the dead, emphasizing consequence. This passage foreshadows New Testament teaching on sin leading to death (Rom. 6:23).

verses.text: She does not ponder the path of life; her ways are unstable, and she does not know them.
verses.comment: Contrast to the way of wisdom (Prov. 4:18). ‘Not knowing’ her ways suggests spiritual blindness—a common theme concerning the effects of sin.

verses.text: Now then, sons, listen to me, and do not turn aside from the words of my mouth.
verses.comment: Renewed appeal to a communal listening—indicative not just of fatherly advice, but of the transmission of revealed truths.

verses.text: Keep your way far from her, and do not go near the door of her house,
verses.comment: Wisdom urges active avoidance of sin. Spiritual disciplines include avoidance and vigilance—an early sense of ordered, disciplined moral life.

verses.text: lest you give your honor to others and your years to the cruel one;
verses.comment: Reference to both social shame and spiritual loss. ‘Years to the cruel one’ implies destruction by sin, reminiscent of warnings in Ecclesiastes about fleeting life.

verses.text: lest strangers consume your wealth and your labor enrich another's house,
verses.comment: Warning against the physical and spiritual consequences of unwise alliances. Echoes themes in Deuteronomy on covenant faithfulness (Deut. 28:30).

verses.text: and at the end of your life, you will groan when your flesh and body are consumed,
verses.comment: Physical consequences of sin reflect spiritual realities—mirroring OT teaching where disobedience results in suffering (Ps. 32:3-4).

verses.text: and you say, 'How I hated instruction and my heart despised reproof!'
verses.comment: The regret over rejecting wisdom echoes the prodigal motif and calls to conversion (cf. Luke 15:17).

verses.text: I did not listen to the voice of my teachers or incline my ear to those who instructed me.
verses.comment: Listening to wisdom through others (elders, teachers) highlights the necessity of receiving truth through appointed guides—pointing toward apostolic, communal guidance.

verses.text: I have come close to complete ruin in the midst of the assembly and the congregation.
verses.comment: ‘Amid the assembly’ underscores the gravity of public sin. In biblical tradition, the community plays a vital role in restoration (see Matt. 18:17).

verses.text: Drink water from your own cistern, running water from your own well.
verses.comment: Marriage is depicted allegorically as a faithfully kept spring—anticipating New Testament teaching on marital faithfulness (Eph. 5:25-33), and Christ as living water.

verses.text: Should your springs be dispersed abroad, streams of water flowing in the streets?
verses.comment: Wastefulness in relationships leads to loss of the richness God intends. Water imagery often points to spiritual vitality (cf. Ps. 1:3).

verses.text: Let them be for yourself alone, and not for strangers with you.
verses.comment: Emphasizes exclusivity of marital relationships, suggesting order and sanctity—foundational for understanding life in community.

verses.text: May your fountain be blessed, and rejoice in the wife of your youth,
verses.comment: Blessing in marriage prefigures spiritual fruitfulness and joy, reminiscent of imagery in Song of Solomon and anticipation of eschatological joy.

verses.text: a loving doe, a graceful fawn. Let her breasts fill you at all times with delight; be intoxicated always in her love.
verses.comment: The delight in marital intimacy is celebrated as holy and joyful—contrasting with illicit pleasures, and pointing to fidelity and exclusiveness.

verses.text: Why should you be intoxicated, my son, with a strange woman or embrace the bosom of a foreigner?
verses.comment: A rhetorical warning—a reminder that true joy is found in ordered relations and covenant fidelity.

verses.text: For the ways of man are before the eyes of the LORD, and He examines all his paths.
verses.comment: God’s omniscience is declared—He sees and judges all. This invites humility and accountability in all actions.

verses.text: His own iniquities will capture the wicked, and he will be held fast by the cords of his sin.
verses.comment: Sin is self-ensnaring—an image reflected in later teaching on spiritual bondage (Rom. 7:23).

verses.text: He will die for lack of discipline, and in the greatness of his folly he will go astray.
verses.comment: Refusal to accept instruction brings spiritual death. The discipline motif here prefigures later teaching on conversion, repentance, and the grace found in submitting to authority and reproof.
